en: Interview with Jacqueline Bridgeman, 2020-01-09

Interview with Jacqueline Bridgeman, an emergency responder with the American Red Cross. Bridgeman recounts coming into Gatlinburg to manage a relief shelter and the steady realization about how sever the disaster was. She also discusses the challenges faced in gathering resources to serve the community and the difficulties in reaching certain branches of the community. This is a representative quote from the interview: "I heard a lot of stories and tried to reassure [the survivors]. There's still a lot of fire going on, we have all of these firetrucks. We have all of these resources. We're gonna help you, it may take a minute, but we will help you."

Interview with Jacqueline Bridgeman, 2020-01-09 -- Rocky Top Sports World
Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Jacqueline Bridgeman, 2020-01-09
Interview Questions
Can you tell me about how long you have been in Tennessee and your background?
Can you tell us about some of the organizations you volunteer with?
How long have you been volunteering?
So volunteering comes from family experience?
What are some of the other events that you have helped with?
What's the longest you have ever been assigned to an event throught the Red Cross?
How did you learn about the fires?
Were the couple running the shelter Red Cross volunteers too?
Restates the established timeline
How long were you the manager on site?
How long did it take to get services to meet the survivors' needs?
During the first night, had any areas been designated for specific purposes?
How long were you the only Red Cross representative at the site?
What does "DR" stand for?
Did you ever reunite with the couple you separated from when arriving in Gatlinburg?
How long did it take before you felt like things were beginning to settle at the facility?
Did you ever get an official count of how many people were serviced at the facility?
Was there enough room inside the facility for everyone?
How did people get to the facility?
Was this the main evacuation facility for the area?
Were people still coming in when you left?
In general, what are the major differences between this and other disasters you have been involved in?
Have you stayed in contact with any of the people you met?
Have you stayed in contact with any of the people you met?
After the first 4-5 day deployment, were you deployed again?
Would you say there were dozens of Red Cross volunteers?
When the headquarters moved from Rocky Top, how far did it move?
Was there any point you felt that you were in danger because of the fire?
How long did your involvement last?
What did you do with the donations?
Were there lessons learned in this event that you'll use going forward?
Do you have any further thoughts about the homeless population around Gatlinburg?
Did you get a sense that any of those individuals were unaccounted for?
Are there other thoughts that you would like to share?
